bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 8, 1879

div1.p: Reed's letter to his wife includes his thoughts on scouting, his work to get the hospital property ready for inspection, an upcoming court martial, and his side-whiskers.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 8, 1879
div1.p:
You may think from the magnitude and extent
of my paper, that I am going to write a very extended communication,
but I assure my little darling that I have not any news at all, & what little
I did intend to say, has been frightened away by this terrific paper!
Now, you talk, lovie, about your nice large paper, but what do think
of mine! Isn't it a “noble” sheet of paper (a la Jerimei Almanach!) I just
thought I would look around now if I couldn't find something
that would give me “Elbow room”, & I almost think I have found it!
Your precious letter of Aug. 20th came yesterday. Mantee was
very glad to hear that his letters always made his darling Emi-
-lie happy and afforded her a few tittillatious of the diaphragm.
He couldn't help from being made sad by the thought that perhaps
his very next letter, which his lovie was complaining of having
to wait for a whole week, would make her very unhappy-
Love her precious, trusting heart! Mantee wishes that it had
been in his power to tell her that he would come this fall,
but his darling wifie knows that it is a matter over which
he has no control, and he hopes so much that his little brave
wifie didn't give way to too many tears! I “pec”, at first.
She had a good “boohoo”, but then I “find” she afterwards “dot” mad,
& said, “Mean old Mantee, I won't cry one bit”! Why just to think,
lovie, it has been a whole month, lacking only a few days, will
I wrote you that I couldn't come till next May? Would you
believe it? When my darling receives this big-sheeteds individual,
it will be after the 25th of the month, and then Mantee will only
have 7 months to stay; & by the time, lovie, you answer this
letter & Mantee replies to yours, why another month will have
Come & gone, & then the New Year will soon be here! I was
sorry that I had not addressed my letter of the 2nd Sept, & which
left here on the 3rd, direct to norfolk- I thought about it quite
awhile, but as you had said that you, sometime about the
Middle of Sept- or after, would leave Harrisonburg, I thought
it would reach you before you started. If you leave on
the 15th, however, you will miss it, lovie, dear- as it cannot
reach H'burg before 16th or 17th. It will reach Norfolk about
the 21st or 22nd, & on opening it, my little lovie will find a
Sung little Check ($10800) for her “Teffigs”! Poor, sweet little wifie, how
the narration of her expenses amused old Mantee! Had
only $40, with which to pay nurse & washing for Aug. & Septr
& pay her expenses to Norfolk! Well, my pretty Emilie,
Mantee takes all the blame upon himself for letting your
purse get so low; but it shout occur again, darling. Why
on the 1st of October, my pretty wifie didn't have as much as $100!
Did she, my pretty pet? Well never mind, my darling, your own husband
will send you another nice check by the middle of November, sure!
Don't write to husband, darling, about hating to spend your money
so much. Husband is perfectly satisfied with our finances - thinks
his darling Emilie has done wonderfully well with her money,
& wants her to feel, when she spends a dollar, that old “tension”
will supply its place with another. I expect to send Pa $50 or
$75 out of our September pay to add to our little mite. Another Octr
pay belongs to darling mama & son. Now that you know you will
spend the writes East, you will, of course, get a nice cloak, my dar-
ling, and a new hat too- Yet just what you need, my wifie, dear, and
don't hesitate a moment on account of money- You must be
as well dressed & pretty as any other lady- Do you intend to re-
main long in Norfolk before going up to Murfreesboro? Write
me just what your plans are for the winter. Mantee will
be so much interested in his precious Emilie's movements, and
if she will tell him before hand just where she will be, he
will always know just where to see his darlings, in his mind's
eye, and enjoy it so much more. I know Romefolks in Murfreesboro
are very anxious to see you again. Take very good care of your
health & papa's boy's health wherever you may be, my lovie, dear.
Papa is reminded of his darling Laurie, every day, by seeing Mrs.
Kingsburg's little boy, who is just 20 months old & a very fine
little fellow. I frequently have a romp with him, but I don't
think he quite comes up to Papa's boy. By the way, is this
not Pa's last year on the Norfolk Circuit? I wonder where
he will be sent. Am sorry that he will not be in Norfolk
all the winter with you- How long will tita remain
up the Country? All winter? Poor Mollie Robinson! What
can make her dislike you, my precious? I thought she con-
-sidered you her friend when you were in Harrisonburg
before. Speaking of Harrisonburg, reminds me that Mr. Gate-
-wood has, at last, returned from his long scout-says his
Mother wrote him that she had met you & that you were
a mighty nice lady, (which I “fought” wasn't anything very
hard to find out, piggie, diggie) and relieved her uneasiness a
good deal by telling her that scouting in Arizona was
not very dangerous. Says that you told her that you
would not be uneasy, if your husband went scouting! Well,
I am glad to hear that my little wifie looks upon it in
that light, which is the sensible way to look as it- not that
I think of going on a scout, for I have no desire whatever-
I find it is much better to remain at home & have something
good to eat & a good Mattrose to sleep on, than to go climbing
over mesas, eat bacon & yeast powder bread, & then sleep
on the ground at night! Although Mr Gatewood only returned
on Friday, he was ordered out again on a scout, to-day, & left
about noon. He had been away from June 19th to Septr 5th,
& left again, to-day. Septr 8th for New Mexico- Don't know when
he will be back- I think he is getting a little tired of life in
the field, & will ask to be relieved, from Indian Company when he gets back again.
Mr Mills is in to see us very frequently- In fact he reminds me
very forcibly of the old woman who never went to visit her son
but twice each year, but stayed six months each time. As his company
is now at Black River, only 18 miles away, and Captain McGowan gives
him permission to absent himself whenever he likes, he does nothing
else but loaf around Apache. Turkey Creek Hill, my darling, is no
more- I went over the new road just made, and it is a beautiful
grade-easy of ascent & decent- & Black River will soon follow suit.
Tuesday, Septr 9th - noon- Well, lovie, dear, old Mantee has been hard
at work all the morning, trying to get a lot of Hospital Property
ready for inspection, as Col. Biddle is expected, to-morrow, or next day-
and a big job I have had of it- Steward Alberti, alias old “ it shall
be most excellent,” is simply the most annoying old “tea-pot”
that I ever had to deal with! He has no idea of keeping things
in order, and doesn't know where to find anything- I wrote to Dr Mc
Kee last week, & asked to have him sent somewheres else, & I do hope
my request will be granted, as I am heartily sick of the old “”
By the way, lovie, I had a letter from Dr Oldmixon, last week. He
is still at McDowell & says the heat is prostrating; wishes that
he was back at Apache. Sends his very kindest regards to “Madame
and Kid”. I presume he is “going” out of the Territory, “next spring”, as he
has been making arrangements to go every spring since I have been
in the Department. We are going to have a “General Court Martial”
here- will meet next Saturday, 13th (I believe I was born on that
day!). Col. Biddle, 6th cav. is president, & the immortal “Billy”, the
ex-conqueror & ex-quartermaster, is judge advocate- As there are
5 or 6 long windeds cases to be tried, & as won “The lazy,” dislikes
to do any work, I think we will be in session about 40 years,
more or less. Lt. Scott, 6th cav., whom you met at Thomas, comes
over from Verde as a member of the Court- I don't know whether
he will bring his wife or not- Mr Overton is engaged in building
the Telegraph line amend from Thomas to Apache, & has his wife & child
along with him- These I believe are about all the Army matters
that I can make & scrape- Our rifle-match for $50 medal, which
was postponed till Captain Heutig's return from Scouting, Ames
off Friday & Saturday of this week- I don't know whether I will
shoot or not, as in a little match that we had, a few days ago,
I became so nervous that, out of 30 who fired, I stood only
No. 6- five others having better scores- No. 6. seems a favorite number
with me, lovie. You remember that my standing in my class in the
Army was also No. 6. and to make the matter perfectly conclusive, I was
appointed District Physician in New York to ward No. 6, and I am No.
6 feet high! Hesche! lovie. This last exclamation reminds me of Papa's
boy- Has he, mother, forgotten how to say “hesche”? He used to say it so
sweetly- Old Juanita, alias “Transportation”, still clings to Apache, &
does a “vast quantity” of washing- Natsin, alias “The Liar,” also pays
me a visit occasionally, & always makes inquiries of my “Motash-”
I believe his “lady” has quite recovered her health & beauty, & once
more graces & chances Apache circles with her loveliness and wit.
The rumor concerning Señor Don Miller leading the the fair & petit
Hosey to Hymeu's Alter, seems to have been premature, and she is still
the prize whom many valorous admirers are striving to win- (Length
of her neck, at percent, 12 inches-wrinkles, 40 million- eye still peering
into the “for beyonds”- you can recall the look- “why, lady, I hadn't
begun to show you what I could do”!) She still continues to darn my
socks with fragments of clothes line- Adrian, my new striker, (you
remember, lovie, the polite, blond young gentleman, who always took
off his hat & said “good morning” so sweetly,) I think will man my
laundress a race in sewing- He is quite an adopt at wielding the
needle, & I no sooner shed a button, so to speak, than he fastens
it on again. I think he does equally as well as altonan, although
he does not possess that profound insight into human nature that
the latter wields with such perfect mastery; but as he wears slip-
-pers & makes no noise when he news about the house, I like him.
I have reserved the most “stumming” piece of intelligence, my pre-
cious piggie, for the last of my letter- Can you guess, what it is, beauty?
not in a century!- Well, lovie, dear, I have got the handsomest
pair of side-whiskers to be seen at Fort Apache! Real, live,
blooming “siders”, such as catch the passing breeze & detain
it in their depths! Oh! if you could only behold them, my little
wifie, you would fall upon them- & weep! They have the most
delicate auburn tint, shading into my favorite “solferma,” and are
the admiration of all the ladies at Apache! Its all I can do, lovie,
to keep them away from them! They have such a desire to tangle
their fingers in their silken webs! Hesche! I allow them now
to float on the breeze, but when the cold weather comes, will tie
them under my chin, to serve as a kind of comforter! “Boodigs”!
Will, perhaps, send you a “lock” of them, one of these days, if
my little wifie will be very “dood.” My mustache is as rampant
as hour ever! “Boodigs”! And this is every single thing I can think
of to write; except to add that you are beyond a doubt, the
very sweetest lovie, the very dearest wifie, that ever lived! “Boodigs”-
Best love to Sister Amie. Mr V. & Children & Pa Reed- also to Mr Charles Lawrence.
Kiss papa's boy forty times for him. Be a dear, good little wifie; love husband and hosp
think of him arround, normal & right as your band never

closer.seg:
P. S. Susie
in all “humbly
doing”- as far
as better in growing
like “good-boy
horse”- nice
tell you more
of her in my
next- forgot
it this time-
“Boodigs”!
